items.title: The week Europe realised it stands alone against Russian expansionism
items.content_html:
Washington‚Äôs Putin-appeasing plan for peace in Ukraine has failed, but many heard death knell sounded for European reliance on US protection

Kaja Kallas, the European Union foreign policy chief, asked her officials this week to dig up the number of times Russia had ‚Äì in its various guises ‚Äì invaded other states in the 20th and 21st centuries. The answer that came back was 19 states, on 33 occasions. Kallas, the former Estonian prime minister, was not just indulging in some form of historical mathematics. She was seeking to make a point that lies at the heart of the dispute between the US and Europe over Ukraine‚Äôs future, a dispute that has again revealed the chasm across the Atlantic about the true nature of the Russian regime.

Kallas reads history books as a leisure activity and ‚Äì drawing on her own country‚Äôs history of Soviet occupation ‚Äì has long maintained that the Soviet Union fell, but its imperialism never did. ‚ÄúRussia has never truly had to come to terms with its brutal past or bear the consequences of its actions,‚Äù she has said, arguing that the nature of the Russian regime means ‚Äúrewarding aggression will bring more war, not less‚Äù: Putin will come back for more.
